Exhibits in these barracks opened on April 16, 2015.<ref name ="BarracksExhibit">{{cite press release | last = Lynch Broch | first = Alisa | publisher = National Park Service | url = http://blog.manzanarcommittee.org/2015/04/17/manzanar-national-historic-site-opens-long-awaited-barracks-exhibit | title = Manzanar National Historic Site Opens Long-Awaited Barracks Exhibit | date = April 17, 2015 | accessdate = May 5, 2015}}</ref> A restored World War II mess hall, moved to the site from Bishop Airport in 2002, was opened to visitors in late 2010.<ref name = "Block14Groundbreaking">{{cite press release | title = Manzanar Barracks Groundbreaking Set For February 13, 2010 | publisher = U.S. National Park Service | date = January 12, 2010 | url = http://blog.manzanarcommittee.org/2010/01/26/manzanar-barracks-groundbreaking-set-for-february-13-2010 | accessdate = May 18, 2010}}</ref><ref name = "LATimes-Boxall">{{cite news | last = Boxall | first = Bettina | publisher = Los Angeles Times | title = Reassembling A Sad Chapter Of History | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2002/dec/11/local/me-manzanar11 | date = December 11, 2002 | accessdate = September 16, 2008 | page = A1}}</ref>
In late 2008, historically appropriate vegetation was planted near the Interpretive Center.<ref name = "Centennial">{{cite press release | publisher = National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior | url = http://blog.manzanarcommittee.org/2008/05/03/manzanar-national-historic-site-receives-funding-from-centennial-initiative | date = May 1, 2008 | title= Manzanar National Historic Site Receives Funding From Centennial Initiative | accessdate = May 18, 2010}}</ref><ref name = "InterpretiveCenterVegetation">{{cite press release | publisher = National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior | url = http://blog.manzanarcommittee.org/2008/11/23/manzanar-completes-centennial-project-with-support-from-friends-of-manzanar | date = November 23, 2008 | title= Manzanar Completes Centennial Project with Support From Friends of Manzanar | accessdate = May 18, 2010}}</ref> The Manzanar National Historic Site also unveiled its virtual museum on May 17, 2010<ref name = "VirtualMuseum">{{cite press release | title = Manzanar National Historic Site Unveils Virtual Museum | publisher = National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior | url = http://blog.manzanarcommittee.org/2010/05/17/manzanar-national-historic-site-unveils-virtual-museum | date = May 17, 2010 | accessdate = May 18, 2010}}</ref> and continues to collect oral histories of former incarcerees and others from all periods of Manzanar's history.
=== Opposition to the creation of the Manzanar National Historic Site === After Congress named Manzanar a National Historic Site and gave the National Park Service the job of restoring the site in 1992, protests against its creation emerged. Letters flooded the National Park Service, demanding that Manzanar be portrayed as a guest housing center for the Japanese Americans.<ref name = "LATimes-Whitewash">{{cite web | last = Jones | first = Robert A .| url = http://articles.latimes.com/1996-04-10/local/me-56927_1_veterans-groups | title = Whitewashing Manzanar: Various Veterans Groups want To (Bully) The Government Into Denying The Site of its Historic Meaning | publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]| date=April 10, 1996 | accessdate= May 15, 2015}}</ref> William Hastings, of Bishop, California, wrote to the National Park Service, saying that the portrayal of Manzanar as a concentration camp amounts to "treason."<ref name = "LATimes-Whitewash" /> Protesters threatened to start dismissal campaigns against Bill Michael, a member of the Manzanar Advisory Commission who was the Director of the [http://www.inyocounty.us/ecmsite/ Eastern California Museum] in Independence, California, and Superintendent Ross Hopkins, the National Park Service employee assigned to the site.<ref name = "LATimes-Whitewash" /> They also threatened to destroy any buildings erected or restored at Manzanar.<ref name = "LATimes-Bitter">{{cite web | last = Forstenzer | first = Martin | url = http://articles.latimes.com/1996-04-04/news/mn-54883_1_manzanar-internment-camp | title = Bitter Feelings Still Run Deep at Camp | publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]] |date = April 4, 1996 | accessdate = May 15, 2015}}</ref> Further, [[Lillian Baker]], and others in California, objected to the words, "concentration camp" on the California State historical marker,<ref name = "LATimes-Bitter" /> which has been hacked and stained, with the first "C" of "concentration camp" having been ground off.<ref name = "LATimes-Bitter" /> Further, a man, who described himself as a World War II veteran, called Hopkins to say that he had driven 200 miles to urinate on the marker.<ref name = "LATimes-Bitter" />
==In popular culture== A made-for-television movie, ''[[Farewell to Manzanar]]'', directed by John Korty, aired on March 11, 1976, on [[NBC]]. It was based on the 1973 memoir of the same name, written by [[Jeanne Wakatsuki Houston]], who was incarcerated at Manzanar as a child, and her husband James D. Houston. The book and the movie tell the story of the Wakatsuki family and their experiences behind the barbed wire through young Jeanne's eyes.<ref name = "FarewellBook">{{cite book | author = Houston, Jeanne Wakatsuki | title = Farewell To Manzanar: A True Story of Japanese American Experience During and After the World War II Internment | publisher = Laurel Leaf | origyear = 1973| year = 1983 | isbn = 0-553-27258-6}}</ref><ref name = "DiscoverNikkeiJWH">{{cite web | title = Discover Nikkei: Jeanne Wakatsuki Houston | url = http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/interviews/profiles/61/ | publisher = DiscoverNikkei.org | date = November 25, 2006 | accessdate = November 18, 2010}}</ref> On October 7, 2011, the [[Japanese American National Museum]] (JANM) announced that they had negotiated the rights to the movie, and that they would make it available for purchase on DVD.<ref name = "JANM-DVD">{{cite web | last = Newman | first = Esther | title = Farewell to Manzanar on DVD-Timeless and Timely | url = http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/journal/2011/10/7/farewell-to-manzanar | publisher = Japanese American National Museum | date = 2011-10-07 | accessdate = 2011-10-11}}</ref><ref name = "FTM-Rafu">{{cite news | title = A New Beginning for "Farewell to Manzanar" | url = http://www.rafu.com/2011/10/a-new-beginning-for-farewell-to-manzanar | last = Yamamoto | first = J.K. | publisher = Rafu Shimpo | date = October 27, 2011 | accessdate = June 4, 2016}}</ref>
''[[Come See The Paradise]]'' was a feature film about how forced relocation and imprisonment at Manzanar affected a Japanese American family from Los Angeles and a European American union organizer. The film, released in 1990, starred [[Dennis Quaid]] and [[Tamlyn Tomita]], and was written and directed by Alan Parker.<ref name="NYTImes-CSTP">{{cite news | last = James | first = Caryn | url = http://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9C0CE0D91F3EF930A15751C1A966958260 | title = Review/Film; When a Population Was Victimized at Home | work = New York Times | date = December 23, 1990 | accessdate = April 23, 2016}}</ref>
Folk/country musician [[Tom Russell]] wrote "Manzanar", a song about the Japanese American internment, that was released on his album ''Box of Visions'' (1993).<ref name = "Billboard.com">{{cite web | title = Box of Visions – Tom Russell (1993) | url = {{BillboardURLbyName|artist=tom russell|chart=all}} | publisher = Billboard | date = April 10, 2003 | accessdate = May 2, 2010}}</ref> [[Laurie Lewis]] covered the song on her album ''Seeing Things'' (1998), adding the Japanese string instrument, the [[koto (musical instrument)|koto]], to her performance.<ref name = "BlueGrassWorks">{{cite web | author = Geffen, Lewis| title = Laurie Lewis | url = http://www.bluegrassworks.com/profile.php?profileID=26 | publisher = Bluegrass Works LLC | date = January 1, 2004 | accessdate = December 24, 2007}}</ref>
The 1994 award-winning novel, ''[[Snow Falling on Cedars]]'' by David Guterson, contains many scenes and details relating to Japanese Americans from the [[Puget Sound]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], area and their incarceration experiences at Manzanar.<ref name = "Cedars">{{cite book | author = Guterson, David | title = Snow Falling On Cedars | publisher = Vintage | year = 1995 | isbn = 0-679-76402-X}}</ref><ref name = "UW">{{cite web | title = Aggressive Regionalism: Commentary: 16. David Guterson, Snow Falling on Cedars | url =https://www.washington.edu/uwired/outreach/cspn/Website/Classroom%20Materials/Reading%20the%20Region/Aggressive%20Regionalism/Commentary/16.html | publisher = Center For The Study Of The Pacific Northwest, University of Washington | accessdate = April 23, 2016}}</ref> The [[Snow Falling on Cedars (film)|2000 film]] based on the book also details that connection.
The Asian American jazz fusion band [[Hiroshima (band)|Hiroshima]] has a song entitled "Manzanar" on its album ''The Bridge'' (2003). It is an instrumental song inspired by Manzanar and the Japanese American incarceration.<ref name = "HiroshimaBridge">{{cite web | title = Bridge | publisher = Hiroshima, Inc. | url = http://www.hiroshimamusic.com/bridgereview.html |date=October 2003 | accessdate = May 27, 2007}}</ref> Also, its song "Living In America", on its album titled ''East'' (1990), contains the phrase "I still remember Manzanar."
[[Fort Minor]]'s song "[[Kenji (song)|Kenji]]", from the album ''[[The Rising Tied]]'' (2005), tells the true story of [[Mike Shinoda]]'s family and their experiences before, during, and after World War II, including their imprisonment at Manzanar.<ref name=" ShinodaInterview">{{cite news | title = MorleyViews: Interviews by Morley Seaver: Mike Shinoda (Linkin Park, Fort Minor) | publisher = AntiMusic/Iconoclast Entertainment Group | url = http://www.antimusic.com/morley/05/FortMinor.shtml | accessdate = September 24, 2007}}</ref>
[[Channel 3 (band)|Channel 3]]'s song titled "Manzanar" is about the incarceration.<ref name = "Channel3">{{cite web | title = Song Meanings – Lyrics – Channel 3 – Manzanar | publisher = SongMeanings | url = http://www.songmeanings.net/lyric.php?lid=3530822107858628118 | date = September 30, 2006 | accessdate = September 24, 2007}}</ref>
In the 1984 movie ''[[The Karate Kid]]'', Kesuke Miyagi's wife and new-born son die during child birth on November 2, 1944 while in the Manzanar Relocation Camp. Mr. Miyagi is fighting for the US against the Germans in Europe when he received the news.<ref name = "LAWeekly">{{cite news | last = Cowan | first = Jared | title = How a Movie Shot in the San Fernando Valley Made Us All The Karate Kid | url = http://www.laweekly.com/arts/how-a-movie-shot-in-the-san-fernando-valley-made-us-all-the-karate-kid-4790700 | work = LA Weekly | date = June 17, 2014 | accessdate = April 23, 2016}}</ref>
A 2007 episode of the [[CBS]] television crime drama ''[[Cold Case (TV series)|Cold Case]]'', titled "Family 8108", dealt with the 1945 murder of a Japanese American man in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] after he and his family were released from Manzanar. The episode originally aired on December 9, 2007.<ref name = "ColdCasetv.com">{{cite web | title = Cold Case: Family 8108 – TV.com | url = http://www.tv.com/cold-case/family-8108/episode/1142751/summary.html | year = 2007 | accessdate = December 10, 2007}}</ref>
